Detailed Description

A player that plays according to a Finite State Automaton.

Players instantiated using this class will make decisions based upon a text representation of a finite state machine. The player's move is specified as a sequence of states:

Machine Author
Machine Name
Number of states (unsigned int)
State 0
State 1
...
State N-1

The format for a given state is as follows:

<move>, <next state if opponent moves C>, <next state if opponent moves D>

The list of states is zero-indexed (that is, the first state played in a given game is state 0, not state 1).

A simple FSA implementation of the tit-for-tat algorithm would be expressed as follows:

Charles Pence
TitForTat
2
C, 0, 1
D, 0, 1

Hopefully this is enough documentation that the machines are reasonably understandable.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

FSAPlayer::FSAPlayer ( )

Constructor.

The constructor initializes the instruction pointer to an invalid value (which will be reset on machine load).

FSAPlayer::FSAPlayer ( const FSAPlayer &  p)

Copy constructor.

Parameters:
pPlayer to be copied

Member Function Documentation

virtual Player* FSAPlayer::Clone ( ) const [virtual]

Create a newly allocated copy of the current player.

To properly implement an "add player" event (wxEVT_ADD_PLAYER), we need to be able to create an arbitrary copy of a given player, without knowing its type at runtime. This method returns an exact duplicate of the current object, and is simply implemented as return new [Type](*this);.

Returns:
A copy of the current player

Implements Player.

bool FSAPlayer::DoLoad ( const Game *  game,
const wxArrayString &  fsaScript 
) [private]

Internal function which actually loads the FSA script.

This is the generalized loading code, called by both Load() and LoadFromString().

Parameters:
gameThe game against which to check the player moves
fsaScriptThe script file to be loaded, an array of lines
Returns:
True if the file is successfully loaded, false otherwise

bool FSAPlayer::LoadFromString ( const Game *  game,
const wxString &  fsaScript 
)

Load a finite state machine script from a string.

Load the source code for this player's finite state machine from the given string. This is useful primarily for testing.

Parameters:
gameThe game against which to check the player moves
fsaScriptThe finite state script to be loaded
Returns:
True if the file is successfully loaded, false otherwise
virtual void FSAPlayer::Reset ( ) [virtual]

Reset the internal FSAPlayer state.

The FSAPlayer must override the Reset method in order to clear the eip variable.

Reimplemented from Player.

bool FSAPlayer::Think ( const Game *  gamePlayed,
const Player *  nextOpponent 
) [virtual]

Determine the next game move.

This function sets nextMove based upon some function of pastGames[&nextOpponent].

Note:
The behavior of the Think function should not depend on anything but the identity (i.e. address) of nextOpponent -- in particular, cheating (reading the value of nextOpponent->nextMove, that is) will do you no good, because you have no guarantee whether or not nextOpponent has had its Think function called already.
Parameters:
gamePlayedThe game currently being played
nextOpponentThe opponent which is currently being played
Returns:
True if move was made successfully, false otherwise

Implements Player.
